From my own experience, you really don't need a very concentrated NaOH solution to react with the aluminium at a reasonable speed. 1-2 tablespoons per liter of water should be plenty enough. This has the benefit of reducing the need of cooling to just placing the reaction vessel in a large enough water bath. No need for ice. I would also suggest adding the aluminium to the lye instead of vice versa. This way you can avoid hot spots and you have more control over the heat generated in general.

>Mege-Mouries' original margarine was vastly different from today's
product, for until 1900 it was made entirely of products of animal
origin and until 1906 it contained no hydrogenated oils or fats. The
main ingredient was oleo oil derived from tallow (beef fat). To make
margarine choice grade, edible tallow (with a melting point of
approximately 49°C or 120°F) was ground and heated in water at
relatively low temperature. A little potassium carbonate and the
stomachs of two sheep or pigs were added per ton. The pepsin from the
stomachs (enzymes were just then coming to be understood) was supposed
to break down the fat tissues, aiding in extraction of the fat. The
liquid fat, which floated to the surface and was decanted off, was
called "oleo stock" in English or premier jus in French. This
was poured into shallow pans and allowed to crystallize slowly at about
30°C (86°F). The resulting granular mass was wrapped in filter cloths
and pressed hydraulically. The resulting liquid, which comprised about
60% of the volume of the oleo stock, had a melting point lower than that
of the original tallow, about 31°C or 88°F. This liquid was called
"oleo oil" in English, but "oleomargarine" in French. Note that at
typical room temperature oleo oil would become a soft plastic semisolid,
with much the same "melt in the mouth" consistency as butter at room
temperature. The solid fat remaining in the filter cloths had a higher
melting point than the original tallow (about 52°C or 126°F) and was
called "oleostearine." Now, to make margarine, 30 kg of cooled oleo oil/
oleomargarine were mixed with 25 kg each of cow's milk and of
water in a butter churn fitted with an agitator. To this was added 100
gm of macerated fresh cow's udder, which was believed to contain an
enzymelike substance that promoted formation of milk emulsion in cows.
The mixture was agitated at the body temperature of a cow for 2-3 hours
and the resulting emulsion was then handled by the butter making
process. Ice cold water was added to the churn to solidify the emulsion.
The mixture was finally salted and excess water was drained, then
kneaded out. The plastic mass was pounded into barrels for sale as bulk
margarine. A good butterlike flavor resulted, not from the intended
enzymatic digestion, but from a bacterial fermentation and souring in
the milk. If the new product had not been tasty, the sophisticated
French palate would not have accepted it so quickly (Schwitzer 1956). It
should be emphasized that, considering the state of the art at that
time, Mege-Mouries's invention was an extraordinary development. For the
first time, even though by accident, it established the principle of
treating fats other than butterfat with milk to produce a flavor like
that of butter.

There is one thing you kinda got wrong here, you cannot buy margarine or butter below fat content of 80%, regardless of saturate/unsaturated ratios or animal/plant fat used.. In Europe and possibly also the US(not 100% sure the FDA regulates this part) it is part of consumer protection, that because of the historical connotations mainly the words butter but also to a lesser extent margarine have, you are legally forbidden from defining your product as margarine or butter without 80% fat content.
Also the three "butters/margarine" you show, Imperial uses Margarine on the package, Becel uses Margarine on the package, Table lands does not, the first two are above 80% fat content, the third is around 52%.

To show this concept in action, people can look up Israel, Heinz and how they cant use Ketchup on their bottles, because the tomato content is below 39%, this they have to use "tomato sauce" instead of Ketchup. This is specific for Israel but most western countries have similar rules in place, in general, in order to prevent big companies from directly fleecing consumers.

To make a good emulsion, you should mix the water and emulsifier together first and vigorously stir this combination while adding the fat very slowly. The rate at which you add the fat should be one drop/sec at first and then increase the rate of addition as you go (but never dump a large amount in as this can break the emulsion, even if you do it right at the very end).

The idea is to increase the surface area of the water while the fat is slowly dispersed into the mixture. Going the other way around might be possible, but would require a lot more energy in stirring, as it's difficult to add air to a large amount of fat.

Source: I have 10 years of experience in the food and beverage industry.

For the hydrogen production step, why not use electrolysis? A couple of graphite electrodes (or platinum if you can afford it) and a dilute solution of sulfuric acid will do it. The amount of acid required is tiny (even 1% would be more than enough), so this is far less dangerous than using a 50% solution of sodium hydroxide. Concentrated caustic solutions are not pleasant to deal with. I would imagine that your dropping funnel ended up etched and the glass barrel of the stopcock would probably also be damaged.

You can also control the rate of hydrogen production by altering the current flow (by changing the voltage), which directly translates to rate of reaction in electrolysis. So you could even rig it to send the hydrogen directly into the hydrogenation flask without using balloons. You wouldn't necessarily need a valve either, since the hydrogen flow could be stopped immediately by cutting power to the electrolysis cell. In your video, the leak in the system is likely the balloon itself. Rubber is permeable to gases and hydrogen diffuses through rubber faster than any other gas.

This was a fun video. I'd never really looked into the history of margarine before, and I didn't realize the production could be this simple. I also liked the explanations about different forms of triglycerides. I don't have much experience with chemistry as a science, but I do have a lot of experience with applied chemistry (ie: cooking), so I noticed some things that might improve your product, if you want to do a real edible chem video on this later, like when you redid the capsaicin videos. From a cooking perspective, I'm thinking that you need:

1) Far less lecithin. Seriously, that looks like little enough product that a single egg yolk would be enough---and there's a lot of stuff in egg yolk other than emulsifiers---and it looks like you used more lecithin than the volume of an egg yolk.

2) More unsaturated fat mixed into the final product. That's just a guess, though.

3) Less water. With an emulsifier like lecithin, you should be able to get more than 2 parts fat to 1 water by volume. (I've made mayonnaise (which is basically the same thing as margarine, but with almost all unsaturated (liquid) fat out of a few tablespoons of water-based liquid and several cups of oil.)

4) Some flavors. Even if the texture came out perfect, just partially hydrogenated fat emulsified with water won't taste like much of anything. You need some salt at the very least, and maybe some butter flavor (available in most supermarkets, at least in the US, and I can't imagine they wouldn't be available in Canada).

5) Far more vigorous stirring. The most important part of making a decent emulsion isn't the emulsifier, but the stirring. The emulsifier prevents it from separating over time, but in order to make the emulsion in the first place, I'd've used a stir bar. For larger amounts, a whisk can be used (although your arms will probably be numb by the time you finish), or an immersion blender. A food processor or bar blender can also be used, but you'll have to be careful not to over-mix. Another advantage of using blenders and whisks is that you introduce more air into the mixture. Since you're past the hydrogenization step at that point, air isn't a problem chemically, and air bubbles help to soften the final product.

Hope this helps in your kitchen if not in the lab. Now I'm thinking of picking up some partially hydrogenated vegetable oils (probably a mix of shortening and olive oil, since I don't have a lab setup) and seeing if I can make margarine at home.

Assuming you know
Simply put, humans can almost only handle fats that have all the hydrogen atoms in rows, cis-bonds. If there is a random hydrogen atom on the wrong side of the carbon chain, no second hydrogen atom on the cis-bond side of the chain and that hydrogen has an "empty" site on the corresponding site of the carbon atom in front of and behind it in the chain, it can't be used by humans and can't be identified by scavenger receptors once they've entered the human body. That's why they have such a significant impact in the form of causing earlier morbidity in several otherwise age-related diseases. Completely different mechanism compared to cholesterol but almost identical long term effects.

Perhaps the medical definition of "trans" differs from chemistry? As long as there is one continous row of hydrogen atoms on any one side of the chain, it's considered cis. This is because as long as there is a continous row of hydrogen atoms on at least one side, the enzymes can still strip the electrons (well, hydrogen atoms) away.

Cis according to medicine: (Forgive my ASCII skills)

H-C-H
H-C
H-C-H

Also Cis according to medicine:
H-C
H-C
H-C

Trans:

C-H
H-C
C-H

Once the enzyme reaches an empty "H" slot it assumes the entire chain has been stripped of hydrogen atoms, but the enzyme that's supposed to split the empty carbon chain can't work if there are any hydrogen atoms left on the chain. So you end up with the rear half of an oil-chain that can't be "split" completely by human enzymes, and can't be identified as foreign material by the receptors on the immune system's scavenger cells. So it just gets left as random slagg in the body.

It's really only used as a cheaper alternative to oils with a pre-determined set of properties, or other additives with no adverse health effects. These properties can be set by GMO or by old school plant breeding. The producer saves a few cents per portion (as compared to using purpose designed vegetable oil) but society loses large sums of money and there's a bit of suffering and human tragedy as well.

Margarine nowadays is generally produced from interesterified fat rather than partially-hydrogenated, actually, due to the health concerns associated with trans fats.

That said, though, some tips for a more apt 'general-purpose' margarine formulation:
-Around 60% unsaturated + 20% saturated fats (75:25 unsaturated-to-saturated ratio)
-Around 20% water
-Up to 0.5% emulsifiers; generally 0.2-0.3% lecithin + 0.1-0.2% glycerol mono-/distearate (the lower the amount of saturated fats, the higher the amount of the diester; mono-/diester ratio not too important for this example - it's more for low-fat spreads)
-Adjust the pH of the water phase (water, preservative, colour, flavour) to 4.5 (via citric or lactic acid) before adding it to the fat phase
-Use strong shear during the emulsification step to ensure better dispersion of the droplets. Something like a stick blender might work for larger batches, but could introduce large air bubbles in smaller ones.

You can generally find example formulations for commercial-esque products on the websites of their specialty ingredients (eg. Palsgaard). Granted, most of us don't have all the equipment called for, but it gives you a starting point.

Right out of my undergrad I worked as an analytical chemist for a large fortune 30 food ingredient company. I worked with atomic emission spectroscopy, to determine the levels of various metals in our waste water, oil products, and various niche products. My least favorite samples to run were the fully hydrogenated soy wax that is used as a coating for Dixie cups. I had to heat the samples in a microwave, weigh them and mix them with hot kerosene before they re-solidified. Running them through the instrument was its own special hell, involving a heat gun and a dry block tube heater that kept the kerosene around boiling so the wax wouldn't precipitate and solidify in feed tubing or the glass spray nozzle of the vacuum feed.

We also made lecithin, which was fun to work with. I'd always amaze our interns by showing them how much water could be emulsified in a given volume of oil with very little lecithin. If I had to hazard a guess as to one of the issues with the texture of your final product, it would be that you really overdid the lecithin. It should've taken less than 1mL to emulsify your full batch. Also the water seemed low, I would aim for at least 40% water plus or minus some depending on your fat content.

I've actually worked on industrial sized hydrogenation vessels. They were about 4 m tall and 2 m across. The inside of the vessel is lined with stainless coils that can either heat or cool the mix. The hydrogen is pumped in through a 1 m sparging ring at the bottom. There's also a driveshaft that runs up the center with several sets of paddles attached to it. The work usually involved re-tightening the bolts for the coils, removing the sparging ring because it would regularly plug up, and replacing the bushings and seals for the mixing shaft.
The insides of the vessel would over time build up a heavy black coating of stuff that resembled hard spongy plastic.
Also, the catalyst the plant used was nickel based. On occasion, the spent catalyst bin would spontaneously combust.
